section.title: Introduction
section.para: Installation of PyLith on a desktop or laptop machine is, in most cases, very easy. Binary packages have been created for the most common platforms, including Linux, OSX, and Windows. Installation on machines that are not compatible with any of these operating systems requires building the software from the source code, which can be difficult for inexperienced users.

section.title: Getting Help
section.para: Help is available via the CIG Short-Term Crustal Dynamics Mailing List and CIG's issue tracking system.

section.title: Requesting help
section.para: The CIG Short-Term Crustal Dynamics Mailing List, cig-short@geodynamics.org, is a mailing list dedicated to CIG issues associated with short-term crustal dynamics, including the use of PyLith. You can subscribe to the mailing list and view messages at the CIG website.

section.title: Reporting bugs and errors
section.para: CIG uses the Roundup for bug tracking. If you find a bug in PyLith, please submit a bug report to the CIG Roundup system. Of course, it is helpful to first check to see if someone else already submitted a report related to the issue; one of the CIG developers may have already posted a solution to the problem. You can reply to a current issue by clicking on the issue title. To submit a new issue, click on Create New under Issues.

section.title: Installation
section.para: Binary executables are available for three of the most widely used platforms: 32-bit Linux, Mac OSX, and Windows. If your platform is not compatible with any of these, you can build the software from the source code.

section.title: Linux
section.para: Running the Linux binary version of PyLith requires a 32-bit compatible machine with GLIBC 2.2 or later.

listitem.para: Unpack the tarball in a suitable location.

Add pylith-0.8-linux-x86/bin to your PATH. You will likely want to add something like
PATH=${PATH}:replace_with_absolute_path/pylith-0.8-linux-x86/bin
to your .bashrc file (if you are using bash as your shell) or the equivalent to your .cshrc file (if you are using tcsh as your shell).

Add pylith-0.8-linux-x86/lib to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH. You will likely want to add something like
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}:replace_with_ absolute_path/pylith-0.8-linux-x86/lib
to your .bashrc file (if you are using bash as your shell) or the equivalent to your .cshrc file (if you are using tcsh as your shell).
To uninstall PyLith, simply remove the pylith-0.8-linux-x86 directory and all of its sub-directories.

section.title: Mac OSX
section.para: The OSX binary version was built to run on the Macintosh PowerPC architecture with OSX version 10.2 or later. The binary will run on the Macintosh Intel architecture, but only in emulation mode (i.e., rather slowly).

listitem.para: Double click on the disk image to mount the disk.
Double click on the disk and copy the PyLith folder to a suiteable location.
To run PyLith, double click on the PyLith icon provided in the PyLith folder.
To uninstall PyLith, simply drag the PyLith folder to the trash.

section.title: Windows
section.para: This Windows binary version of PyLith should be compatible with Windows NT, Windows 2000, and Windows XP.

listitem.para: Double click on the setup.exe file you just downloaded and follow the instructions for installing.
To run PyLith, double click on the PyLith icon on the desktop or select StartAll ProgramsPyLithPyLith
To uninstall PyLith, simply select StartAll ProgramsPyLithUninstall PyLith .

section.title: Building from source
section.para: Building PyLith from the source code is not a trivial task because PyLith depends on several other packages. In general, each package must be compiled from source using compilers for each language that are compatible with one another. The stable version of the PyLith source code is available from the Geodynamics subversion repository under cig/short/3D/PyLith/branches/pylith-0.8.

The software must be built starting from the bottom of the dependency list and working upwards. The steps below describe the recommended way to build PyLith and the external packages on which it depends. Some of the dependencies can be satisfied using precompiled binaries (e.g., RedHat and Fink packages). When considering whether to use a precompiled binary package to satisfy any of the dependencies, remember that all of the compilers and settings used in building the code must be compatible.
